title: Custom Reporting for Acme
description: Acme's procurement team needs quarterly reports in XLSX format with their specific KPI layout. We told them we'd have it by Q1. Engineering says 'depends what you mean by custom.'

outcomes.clear_success: Acme's buyer called it acceptable in Slack. The renewal is no longer actively at risk, which Finance calls a win.
outcomes.partial_success: Reports generate, but they query 47 tables. Procurement got what they needed and support now owns a bespoke view forever.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: A competitor copied the UI. Sales got two demo requests from Acme's competitors asking for the same thing. Unforced error.
outcomes.soft_failure: Report generation takes three minutes. The CFO opened it once, closed it, and moved on. It exists, nobody checks it.
outcomes.catastrophe: The XLSX export included six months of deleted user data. Legal got a call from Acme's compliance officer and the renewal froze pending a data audit.

title: Demo Environment Isolation
description: Three enterprise prospects want to see 'clean' data—not their competitors' workflows in the shared demo. Sales committed to a sandbox. It's complicated.

outcomes.clear_success: All three prospects closed. Sales sent a Venmo request as a joke. Infrastructure now has four temporary Docker instances from 2021.
outcomes.partial_success: Two prospects got sandboxes and entered trials. The third's data was mixed up for a day. They are still moving forward, but cautious.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: A prospect demanded production-scale testing. You spun an environment with two million records and an $1,800 AWS bill. They used it for four hours.
outcomes.soft_failure: One sandbox did not sync custom fields. Sales blamed engineering, engineering blamed the migration script, and the deal slowed to a crawl.
outcomes.catastrophe: A demo environment exposed PII from another customer's test account. Legal and Sales had a tense call. The prospect now defines everything in the SLA as critical.

title: Salesforce Integration
description: TechCorp's entire workflow lives in Salesforce. They need real-time sync or they won't move. Deal size: $400k. Engineering estimates 8 weeks.

outcomes.clear_success: TechCorp signed and the integration became the flagship reference. Sales now uses Salesforce-native in every deck.
outcomes.partial_success: Integration works but sync runs every 30 minutes instead of real time. TechCorp accepted it. It feels like a compromise that cost six weeks.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: The integration is so tight that TechCorp's Salesforce admins joined your escalation chain. Support queues got longer, not shorter.
outcomes.soft_failure: Sync breaks every time TechCorp runs monthly data cleanup. They are in trial, the relationship is tense, and the deal is marked at risk.
outcomes.catastrophe: Salesforce API rate limits were exceeded mid-quarter. Forty-seven hours of unsynced data. TechCorp thought deals closed when they had not. They fired the integration and demanded a refund.

title: CSV Export for Apex
description: Apex Finance needs to export all their analytics to CSV for their legacy reporting tool (which nobody has touched since 2019). It's a deal condition.

outcomes.clear_success: CSV exports. Apex is happy, now referenceable, and the feature took 80 lines of code with zero follow-up questions.
outcomes.partial_success: CSV works but the column order does not match Apex's legacy system. They manually reordered, signed, and grumbled.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Three other customers asked for CSV export immediately. Sales said yes to all of them. You now have an undocumented feature with four requirements.
outcomes.soft_failure: The export hangs on datasets over 50k rows. Apex has 120k. They tried once, it failed, they stopped.
outcomes.catastrophe: The CSV used raw timestamps. Apex's legacy system could not parse them and the deal fell apart because your product cannot integrate with anything.

title: Dedicated Success Portal
description: GlobalTech (800-seat enterprise) demands a private portal for onboarding assets, documentation, and training videos. We promised it in the contract.

outcomes.clear_success: GlobalTech onboarding was 40% faster than previous cohorts. They are pushing for co-marketing and Success now has a new template.
outcomes.partial_success: Portal shipped. Sixty percent of GlobalTech users found it and asked for more email reminders. It exists and is fine.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: GlobalTech used the portal to document internal processes and now wants customization and their logo. This is becoming a sub-product.
outcomes.soft_failure: The portal was built but never publicized internally at GlobalTech. The email landed in spam. Three months in, only 15 users accessed it.
outcomes.catastrophe: A support video went live with internal passwords visible. GlobalTech escalated to their board. You are now on a mandatory audit schedule with a $50k indemnity clause.

title: Custom SLA Monitoring
description: BigBank's legal team will only sign if we provide real-time SLA alerts and breach reporting. Infrastructure to build, customer to implement. Nobody has estimated it yet.

outcomes.clear_success: BigBank signed a $1.2M three-year deal. The SLA dashboard is so comprehensive that Finance uses it for vendor management.
outcomes.partial_success: SLA monitoring works, but alerts sometimes arrive five minutes late. BigBank accepted it and left a standing monthly review call to mention it.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: BigBank's ops team now treats the dashboard as source of truth. They filed three formal incidents based on non-critical alerts.
outcomes.soft_failure: The dashboard tracks uptime, not performance SLAs. BigBank wanted P95 latency. You built uptime. They use it grudgingly.
outcomes.catastrophe: A calculation bug showed you in breach for 18 hours when you were not. Finance demanded a $200k credit and the relationship turned litigious.

title: White-Glove Onboarding Flow
description: Citadel Fund needs a bespoke, guided setup with pre-filled configurations and handoff to a dedicated success manager. Sales promised it. It's a strategic account.

outcomes.clear_success: Citadel went live in 10 days. Success now has a repeatable playbook and Sales is selling white-glove as a premium tier.
outcomes.partial_success: Onboarding took three weeks instead of 10 days. Citadel is live and functional. They did not complain, but they did not rave either.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Citadel wants the same treatment for a new team next quarter. Success is now stuck delivering bespoke experiences on repeat.
outcomes.soft_failure: Pre-filled configs covered 70% of the use case. They spent two weeks customizing the rest. The white-glove feeling wore off fast.
outcomes.catastrophe: The assigned success manager left. Citadel demanded someone who knew their setup and nobody did. They are threatening to switch over key person risk.

title: Competitor Displacement Feature
description: Vertex has been using a competitor. They'll switch to us for $500k if we can import their data and migrate their workflows. Sales is very confident. Data schema is completely different.

outcomes.clear_success: Vertex migrated cleanly at 99.8% accuracy. They became a case study and Sales closed three similar deals using the reference.
outcomes.partial_success: Migration hit 98% accuracy. Vertex lost 2,000 historical records in the translation layer and is live but annoyed.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: The tool was so good Vertex used it to audit their own data and found inconsistencies. They now want us to validate their entire history.
outcomes.soft_failure: Migration took twice as long as estimated. Vertex went live with a reduced feature set until manual remapping finished. They feel like second-class citizens.
outcomes.catastrophe: A foreign key issue corrupted 15% of workflow history. Vertex spent three weeks rebuilding and sued for breach and incompetence. The case is still in discovery.

title: Compliance Audit Export
description: Heritage Insurance needs SOC 2 audit trail exports in a specific format their auditors require. It's a deal condition and a renewal risk. We don't even have the data model yet.

outcomes.clear_success: Export tool built in three weeks. Heritage's auditors approved it and they signed for three more years. Finance loves the renewal confidence.
outcomes.partial_success: Export works but misses four event types. Auditors accepted it with caveats and Heritage is nervous about the next audit.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: The export uncovered 12 months of logging gaps. Heritage did not notice, but now it is in their contract.
outcomes.soft_failure: The export runs but the format is non-standard. Auditors manually validated it anyway. The export exists and adds zero audit value.
outcomes.catastrophe: The export included PII that should have been hashed. Auditors flagged it, the board demanded remediation, and the renewal is now held hostage.

title: Data Migration Toolkit
description: Three pending deals (each $250k+) are all requesting data migration from legacy systems. Sales wants a one-time tool to handle all three. Engineering hasn't committed to timelines.

outcomes.clear_success: All three deals signed. The migration tool is now a standard product feature and post-sales runs 15 migrations a quarter with it.
outcomes.partial_success: Two deals closed using the tool. The third needed manual intervention. The tool works but is not as generic as promised, and the team maintains it.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: The toolkit is now the bottleneck for enterprise onboarding. You built something that sounds like infrastructure but behaves like bespoke service.
outcomes.soft_failure: The tool works for 60% of sources. The other 40% needed custom code and every deal needed custom code. You sold a feature that is mostly services.
outcomes.catastrophe: A migration failed mid-process and left data inconsistent. The customer demanded a rollback. You rebuilt their old system to restore and they are suing for downtime.

title: Priority Support Tier
description: Meridian Health is a 1000-seat account. They want 2-hour response SLA and a dedicated support contact. Sales committed. Support team is already understaffed.

outcomes.clear_success: Meridian's satisfaction jumped 35 points. Support has a dedicated Slack channel for escalations and the account is rock solid.
outcomes.partial_success: Response time hits two hours 80% of the time. Meridian is satisfied and support is exhausted. They are billing an extra $200 per hour for the privilege.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Meridian routes all questions through the dedicated contact, urgent or not. Your support person is now a full-time Meridian resource.
outcomes.soft_failure: Response time is reliably two hours, but the dedicated contact cannot escalate. Meridian waits another two hours for actual resolution and is frustrated.
outcomes.catastrophe: Meridian hired away your dedicated contact. They now demand backpay for time spent on-site. You are defending a breach of contract claim and Meridian left a hostile Glassdoor review.

title: Webhook Customization
description: Logistics Co. needs custom webhook payloads and retry logic that doesn't exist in the product. Deal is stalled pending this. Sales promised 'we can do it.'

outcomes.clear_success: Custom webhooks shipped. Logistics Co. integrated with their warehouse system flawlessly and became a case study.
outcomes.partial_success: Payloads are customizable but retry logic is limited to exponential backoff. Logistics Co. built a wrapper and went live.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Two other customers immediately asked for custom webhooks. You just created a new product category and Sales is selling it as premium.
outcomes.soft_failure: Custom webhooks work 90% of the time. Retry logic fails silently in edge cases. Logistics Co. built their own error handling and is not thrilled.
outcomes.catastrophe: A retry loop went infinite and hammered Logistics Co.'s API until their system crashed. Four hours of downtime and they are claiming damages.

title: Partnership API Access
description: DataFlow Partners wants raw API access to build their own integration layer on top of you. It's strategic but requires security review and rate limiting design.

outcomes.clear_success: DataFlow built an integration layer and you are now positioned as an enterprise platform. Three other integrators asked for API access.
outcomes.partial_success: API access granted with rate limits. DataFlow can build, but throttling hits during peak hours and they work around it.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: DataFlow became the only company customers call for advanced integrations. You created a middleman that controls access to your product.
outcomes.soft_failure: API docs were incomplete. DataFlow reverse-engineered half the API and built something brittle. They are frustrated.
outcomes.catastrophe: DataFlow exposed your API spec in a public GitHub repo. Competitors scraped it. You issued an emergency patch, rotated keys, and spent $40k on incident response.

title: Renewal Automation Workflows
description: Synapse Corp. wants to automate their renewal process within your product—reminders, approvals, stakeholder routing. It's a $600k contract condition.

outcomes.clear_success: Synapse's renewal automation runs flawlessly. They renewed in two weeks instead of three months and are pushing for co-marketing.
outcomes.partial_success: Automation works but approvals still need manual intervention. Cycle time dropped 30% and Synapse called it good enough.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: The automation is so effective their procurement team wants to use it for other vendors. You built internal tooling by accident.
outcomes.soft_failure: Automation works but does not integrate with their email system. Routing is manual and cycle time improved only 15%. It feels half-built.
outcomes.catastrophe: A bug auto-approved a renewal on the wrong date. Finance caught it after it hit their books. They want compensation for the rework.

title: Account Hierarchy Modeling
description: Constellation Group operates 47 subsidiary companies. They need an account hierarchy that lets a parent administrator manage all of them. It's a $2M deal.

outcomes.clear_success: Account hierarchy works perfectly. Constellation signed, it became a product feature, and three other multi-subsidiary prospects entered the pipeline.
outcomes.partial_success: The hierarchy works for 95% of their use case. Two subsidiaries need custom structures and manual work, but it is acceptable.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Constellation's hierarchy is so complex that support tickets are four times longer than average. Support is now an org-structure expert.
outcomes.soft_failure: The hierarchy UI is unintuitive. Admins need weekly training. It works, but it is not elegant.
outcomes.catastrophe: A permission inheritance bug leaked one subsidiary's data to another. Legal is involved, GDPR violations are assessed, and you are in mandatory compliance review.

title: Territory Mapping Module
description: Regional distributors need to map customer territories and prevent overlapping assignments. Sales promised it. It's a non-negotiable for three simultaneous deals.

outcomes.clear_success: Territory mapping shipped. All three deals signed and support had minimal onboarding questions. The feature is stable.
outcomes.partial_success: Territory mapping works but cannot handle complex overlaps. Two deals signed and one needed workarounds.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Territory mapping became so useful customers used it for internal resource allocation. You accidentally built workforce management.
outcomes.soft_failure: Territory mapping works but requires heavy manual data entry. One customer abandoned it after a week and went back to spreadsheets.
outcomes.catastrophe: A bulk import overwrote the database instead of inserting. We rebuilt from backups and customers lost three days of territory assignments. Incident response cost $25k.

title: Champion Tracking System
description: Enterprise buyers want to track internal champions and stakeholders within their organization. Sales needs this for account planning. Engineering is skeptical.

outcomes.clear_success: Champion tracking shipped and account managers use it religiously. Four enterprise renewals cited the champion network as a factor.
outcomes.partial_success: Champion tracking works for structure but does not integrate with email or calendar data. Useful, but manual upkeep is required.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Customer success used champion tracking to identify at-risk relationships. The early warning system became more valuable than the original use case.
outcomes.soft_failure: Champion tracking exists but adoption is low. Account managers track champions in CRM notes instead. The feature is present and unused.
outcomes.catastrophe: A bug exposed champion names and contact info in an API response that Google indexed. A customer's org chart became public. Compliance and PR nightmare.

title: Custom Billing Ledger
description: Zenith Financial Services needs a custom billing ledger that reconciles with their own accounting system. Deal is $350k. Finance wants it too, but it's complex.

outcomes.clear_success: The custom ledger integrates perfectly with Zenith's accounting system. Reconciliation is clean every month, the deal is signed, and Finance loves it.
outcomes.partial_success: The ledger works with minor reconciliation differences, usually under $500 a month. Zenith accepts it and Finance calls it acceptable variance.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Your billing system is now the source of truth for Zenith's revenue recognition. You now own their accounting integrity.
outcomes.soft_failure: The ledger generates correct numbers but Zenith's finance team needs a weekly review call to explain the methodology. It works, with hand-holding.
outcomes.catastrophe: A calculation error overstated Zenith's usage by $200k. Finance did not catch it for two months. The audit that followed put you in breach investigation.

title: One-Page ROI Summary
description: Generate a one-page ROI summary PDF with customer metrics and a templated narrative. Sales wants something to attach to late-stage emails. Low effort, high optics.

outcomes.clear_success: ROI summary shipped. Sales uses it in every late-stage deal, cycles shortened, and now they want it auto-filled for every prospect.
outcomes.partial_success: The PDF exists but needs manual edits. Sales still uses it with a note that says numbers approximate.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Prospects forwarded the PDF to finance. Finance asked for methodology and you got invited to three more meetings.
outcomes.soft_failure: The summary lives in the enablement folder. Sales forgets it exists. The PDF is technically live.
outcomes.catastrophe: The ROI template had the wrong baseline assumptions. A prospect caught it and questioned every other claim. The deal stalled.

title: Usage-Based Pricing Model
description: Move from seat-based to usage-based pricing to capture value from power users. Finance projects 23% ARR uplift. Early-stage users will see price increases. Risky but potentially lucrative.

outcomes.clear_success: Usage-based pricing rolled out. Power users pay more and adoption increased 18%. Net ARR is up 21% and NPS dropped six points, which growth will apparently offset.
outcomes.partial_success: The model went live. Twelve percent of users upgraded and mid-market pays more. NPS dropped eight points and churn ticked up two, but growth is still there.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Power users gamed the metrics. You redefined usage three times and the model is now more complex than the product.
outcomes.soft_failure: Usage-based pricing confused the market. Sales spent four times longer on pricing discussions and conversion dipped 20%. You are reverting.
outcomes.catastrophe: An edge case made bills 5x higher for some customers. Forty-seven disputes arrived at once. You issued credits, NPS dropped 18 points, and the stock took a hit.

title: Seat-Based Licensing Tiers
description: Introduce per-seat pricing with feature differentiation by tier. Enterprise gets everything, Pro gets most things, Basic gets foundations. Finance estimates 18% uplift. Users hate paying per person.

outcomes.clear_success: Seat-based pricing shipped. Enterprise deals have structure and upsell velocity increased 25%. Per-seat monetization is now repeatable.
outcomes.partial_success: Seat-based pricing exists but most customers buy the one-size-fits-all Pro tier. Feature gates are ineffective. Revenue grew 8% instead of 18%.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Customers started rotating users between seats to avoid charges. You added usage tracking to stop seat-sharing and earned new complaints.
outcomes.soft_failure: Seat-based pricing confused SMB customers. Sales educates constantly, conversion dropped 15%, and a hybrid approach is back on the table.
outcomes.catastrophe: A loophole let customers pay for five seats and give access to 50 shared accounts. Revenue was lower than before and you renegotiated terms retroactively.

title: Premium Feature Gating
description: Gate advanced features (workflows, integrations, advanced reporting) behind a 'Premium' or 'Enterprise' tier. Free tier stays functional but limited. Expected 15% upgrade rate.

outcomes.clear_success: Feature gates deployed. Eighteen percent of free users upgraded and net new MRR hit $80k/month. NPS dipped four points but growth justified it.
outcomes.partial_success: Feature gating works with an 11% upgrade rate and $45k/month in revenue. Users complain, but adoption is sustainable.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Free users found API workarounds to access gated features. You added API-level checks and triggered a security review.
outcomes.soft_failure: Feature gating reduced discovery. Engagement dropped 20% and upgrade rate was only 6%.
outcomes.catastrophe: A critical bug made all gated features free for eight hours. Ten thousand users discovered them, upgrade rate collapsed to 2%, and you rolled back with a public apology.

title: In-App Upsell Prompts
description: Add contextual upsell prompts when users hit free tier limits. Estimated 8-12% conversion. UX team hates it. Product team is reluctant.

outcomes.clear_success: Upsell prompts deployed. Ten percent conversion on first interaction, revenue impact positive, users tolerate it, NPS barely moves.
outcomes.partial_success: Prompts are live with a 6% conversion rate. Not annoying enough to cause churn and not effective enough to celebrate. Revenue impact is $20k/month.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Prompts triggered mid-workflow and users abandoned. You tuned timing manually like it was a game.
outcomes.soft_failure: Users skipped prompts 95% of the time. Conversion was 0.5%, so you removed them.
outcomes.catastrophe: Prompts triggered in bulk for 50k users and looked like an outage. Support flooded, NPS dropped 12 points, and Twitter called it aggressive selling.

title: Annual Plan Discount Optimization
description: Test annual prepay discounts (5%, 10%, 15%, 20%) to drive upfront revenue and reduce churn. Modeling shows each 5% discount drives 8% net increase in annual subscriptions.

outcomes.clear_success: A 15% discount lifted annual subscriptions 22%. Net revenue rose 16% and churn dropped two points. The CFO is happy, so the experiment is a win.
outcomes.partial_success: Annual plans worked. Twelve percent upgraded, net revenue rose 8%. It is working, just not as modeled.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Annual customers churned right at renewal because they were committed. You lost the month-to-month churn signal.
outcomes.soft_failure: The annual discount campaign had 3% uptake. Most users do not think in annual terms. Revenue impact was minimal.
outcomes.catastrophe: Customers on a 20% annual discount hit product limits mid-year and demanded refunds. You processed $300k and annual unit economics went negative.

title: Premium Support Tier
description: Offer dedicated support, Slack integration, and priority queuing for $500/month add-on. Targeting mid-market. Expected adoption 10-15%.

outcomes.clear_success: Premium support tier launched with 14% adoption and $420k ARR. Support now has tier-1 and tier-2 and premium satisfaction is up.
outcomes.partial_success: Premium support exists with 8% adoption. It is profitable but the support team is stretched. Sustainability is questionable.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Premium users demanded escalation on non-critical issues. Support SLAs became a liability instead of a feature.
outcomes.soft_failure: Premium support reached 5% adoption. Most customers did not see value, revenue is minimal, and deprecation is on the table.
outcomes.catastrophe: A premium customer's Slack channel leaked sensitive conversation when a team member shared it publicly. Compliance issue, customer lawsuit, tier discontinued.

title: Add-On Marketplace
description: Launch a partner add-on marketplace (integrations, templates, extensions). Revenue share 30/70 split. Potential recurring revenue from ecosystem plays. Huge upside if partners build.

outcomes.clear_success: Marketplace launched with 12 partners and hit $60k MRR by month six. The ecosystem grew and partners were incentivized to sell.
outcomes.partial_success: Marketplace has five partners and $15k MRR. Adoption is slower than hoped and partners are lukewarm.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: A partner built a competing product inside the marketplace and undermined direct sales. You added policies to prevent it.
outcomes.soft_failure: Marketplace launched with no partners. Revenue was $0 for four months. You manually recruited two partners and revenue is still minimal.
outcomes.catastrophe: A partner add-on had a security vulnerability that compromised customer data. The marketplace was liable and legal fees exceeded projected revenue for the year.

title: Consumption Metering System
description: Build consumption metering infrastructure to track 10+ product dimensions (API calls, storage, compute minutes, etc.). Enables granular usage-based pricing. High complexity.

outcomes.clear_success: Metering system deployed. Enterprise customers can see consumption and upsell conversations became data-driven. ARR is up 28%.
outcomes.partial_success: Metering works for 8 of 10 dimensions. Coverage is 80% and customers see consumption, but it is incomplete.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Transparent consumption made price-sensitive customers paranoid. They optimized usage to minimize costs and engagement dropped.
outcomes.soft_failure: Metering is buggy and readings are off by 5-10%. Customers do not trust the metrics and usage-based pricing was delayed.
outcomes.catastrophe: Metering errors underbilled $500k over six months. You issued credits and apologies. Customers demanded refunds and two large accounts left.

title: Overage Charges Implementation
description: Add overage charges when users exceed plan limits (API calls, storage, users). Expects 8-12% of accounts will trigger overages. Revenue upside significant but friction high.

outcomes.clear_success: Overages are live. Ten percent of accounts triggered them, revenue is $35k/month, and NPS dipped three points.
outcomes.partial_success: Overages are implemented. Six percent of accounts triggered charges, revenue is $18k/month, and users are frustrated but not churning.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Customers sandbagged usage estimates during signup to avoid overages. Sales accuracy metrics got worse.
outcomes.soft_failure: Overages triggered only 2% of the time. Revenue is $5k/month and customers are careful enough to avoid them.
outcomes.catastrophe: A calculation bug charged one customer $47k for a single month. They threatened to sue, you issued a credit, and they churned anyway.

title: Enterprise Pricing Restructure
description: Move enterprise from per-seat to consumption-based with negotiated minimums. Simplifies sales, improves margins for usage-heavy accounts. But requires renegotiating active contracts.

outcomes.clear_success: Enterprise repricing completed. Eighty percent of accounts renegotiated, margins improved 18%, and sales cycles shortened by three weeks.
outcomes.partial_success: Repricing is done. Sixty percent of accounts renegotiated, margins are up 10%, and 20% of accounts are in contract dispute.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Some customers interpreted repricing as betrayal. Enterprise NPS dropped nine points and churn ticked up.
outcomes.soft_failure: Repricing negotiated but most customers negotiated better terms. Margin improvement was only 3%, not worth the disruption.
outcomes.catastrophe: Repricing went nuclear with two $1M+ accounts. Lawyers were hired, accounts entered legal review, and one threatened to leave. Media called it price gouging.

title: Payment Method Expansion
description: Add wire transfers, ACH, invoice-based billing, and crypto payment options. Removes friction for enterprise and international buyers. Requires banking and compliance work.

outcomes.clear_success: All payment methods are live. Enterprise close rate improved 22% and international deals accelerated. The feature is now standard.
outcomes.partial_success: Wire and ACH work. Invoice billing is half-implemented. Adoption is good but not transformative.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Crypto payments attracted customers in unstable currencies. Volatility became a reconciliation nightmare.
outcomes.soft_failure: Payment methods exist but adoption is minimal. Most customers still use cards and compliance overhead was not worth it.
outcomes.catastrophe: A wire transfer went to the wrong account and $250k disappeared. You traced and recovered it, endured a legal nightmare, and now only allow verified accounts.

title: Dunning Flow Optimization
description: Improve failed payment recovery with smart retry logic, email campaigns, and alternative payment methods. Current recovery rate is 60%. Target 75%+.

outcomes.clear_success: Dunning optimization is live. Recovery rate is 76%, churn dropped two points, and revenue impact is $40k/month.
outcomes.partial_success: Dunning is live. Recovery rate is 70% and revenue is $20k/month. Better, not as much as hoped.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Dunning emails were too aggressive. Some customers complained and churned, so you softened the messaging.
outcomes.soft_failure: The dunning flow barely moved the needle. Recovery rate is 62% and the complexity was not worth it.
outcomes.catastrophe: A dunning email with the wrong customer name went to a large enterprise account. Confusion followed and the account was at risk until you apologized personally.

title: Trial-to-Paid Conversion Optimization
description: Redesign trial experience: onboarding, feature highlights, purchase prompts at optimal moments. Current conversion is 8%. Target 12%+.

outcomes.clear_success: Trial redesign complete. Conversion is 13% and MRR from trials is up 48%. The funnel is now optimized.
outcomes.partial_success: Trial conversion is 10.5%. Improved, not dramatic. Revenue is up 20%.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Prompts appeared too early and trial users skipped features. Activation decreased even though conversion improved.
outcomes.soft_failure: The redesign had minimal impact. Conversion is 8.5% and most people still do not buy.
outcomes.catastrophe: A trial variant extended duration indefinitely. Three thousand users never got charged and discovery happened at month three. Revenue was $200k lower than projected.

title: Pricing Page Redesign
description: Redesign pricing page for clarity, add comparison tables, calculators, and social proof. Current pricing page conversion is 12%. Target 16%+.

outcomes.clear_success: Pricing page redesigned. Conversion hit 15% and revenue from new signups rose 25%. Comparison tables did their job.
outcomes.partial_success: The page is cleaner and conversion is 13%. Marginal improvement with small ROI.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Comparison tables made the product look more expensive than competitors. Negotiation power decreased.
outcomes.soft_failure: The redesign did not move the needle. Conversion is still 12%. It looks nicer, results are the same.
outcomes.catastrophe: A pricing calculator bug showed prices 10x lower. Customers signed up expecting $50 and got billed $500. Disputes flooded support and you manually overrode 200 accounts.

title: Annual Plan Nudge
description: Add an in-app and email nudge to upgrade to annual billing with a small discount. Low effort, should lift cash flow. Tradeoff: can feel pushy if mistimed.

outcomes.clear_success: Annual upgrades jumped 18%. Cash flow looks healthier and leadership calls it easy money.
outcomes.partial_success: Annual upgrades rose 7%. Some users took the deal, others ignored it. It works, just not loudly.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Users asked for refunds after forgetting they chose annual. Support tickets spiked and retention learned new phrasing.
outcomes.soft_failure: The nudge blended into UI noise. Conversion barely moved, but NPS dipped anyway because users noticed the pop-up.
outcomes.catastrophe: A bug pre-selected annual billing at checkout. Chargebacks flooded in, NPS cratered, and finance froze the discount.

title: AI-Powered Feature Suggestions
description: Build an ML model that suggests product features based on user behavior, competitor moves, and usage patterns. Real-time, contextual recommendations. High risk: model hallucinations, user confusion. High upside: engagement +30%, feature discovery +40%.

outcomes.clear_success: AI suggestions shipped. Engagement jumped 28%, feature discovery rose 35%, and self-serve growth beat projections. Model accuracy hit 94% and everyone pretended it was obvious.
outcomes.partial_success: AI suggestions work. Engagement is up 15% and accuracy is 78%. Users find it helpful but not transformative.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: The model suggested features that directly competed with your roadmap. Users wanted them before strategy intended.
outcomes.soft_failure: Accuracy was 64%. Suggestions felt random, users turned it off, and engagement barely moved.
outcomes.catastrophe: The model suggested a delete all data feature to 50k users. Support flooded, churn spiked 8%, and you retrained the model with a public apology.

title: Real-Time Collaboration Layer
description: Add multi-user real-time collaboration (Figma-style cursors, live commenting, simultaneous editing). Major technical lift. Very high risk: infrastructure, data consistency. Upside: team adoption +80%, new segment unlock (design teams, agencies).

outcomes.clear_success: Real-time collaboration is live. Team adoption jumped 75%, design agencies signed, and churn in multi-user accounts dropped 12%. It became the flagship feature.
outcomes.partial_success: Collaboration works but has 1-2% sync issues. Adoption is strong at 60% and users tolerate the bugs because the feature is worth it.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Collaboration became the main use case and the original product became a side quest. Strategy and sales messaging shifted.
outcomes.soft_failure: Collaboration works but adoption is 35%. Most users are still solo and network effects did not materialize.
outcomes.catastrophe: Websocket infrastructure could not handle 50k concurrent users. The system crashed, 2k sessions lost data, and recovery took 12 hours. Trust evaporated and PR followed.

title: Predictive Analytics Engine
description: Build predictive analytics engine that forecasts user churn, revenue, and feature adoption based on behavioral signals. Embedded in product for self-serve use. Hard ML problem. High upside: enterprise TAM + $5M+, competitive moat.

outcomes.clear_success: Predictive engine deployed. Churn predictions are 87% accurate, enterprises use it for planning, and deal size increased 35%. New TAM unlocked.
outcomes.partial_success: The engine works at 72% accuracy. Useful but not perfect, and adoption is 20% of the enterprise base.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Predictions made customers paranoid about their own health. False positives caused panic.
outcomes.soft_failure: Accuracy hit 58%, barely better than random. Enterprise sales interest stayed low.
outcomes.catastrophe: The model flagged 100 customers as high churn risk with 91% confidence. Finance panicked, win-back campaigns went aggressive, and 12 customers churned because they felt distrusted.

title: White-Label Platform
description: Enable customers to white-label the platform and resell it as their own product. Requires multi-tenancy, branding infrastructure, and partner sales playbooks. High risk: cannibalization, partner mismanagement. Upside: channel revenue, network effects, TAM expansion.

outcomes.clear_success: White-label is live. Eight partners are reselling, $2.5M ARR in year one, and TAM expanded 40%. Channel growth finally feels real.
outcomes.partial_success: White-label works with three partners reselling and $400k ARR. Growth is slower than hoped but still profitable.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: One partner became a competitor and ate into direct sales. Partner conflict management became a full-time job.
outcomes.soft_failure: White-label shipped but only one partner was interested. Revenue is minimal and infrastructure cost is not justified.
outcomes.catastrophe: A partner's brand infringement triggered a trademark dispute. Legal fees exceeded channel revenue, the partner sued for IP ownership, and you shut down the program.

title: Ecosystem Marketplace
description: Build an extensible marketplace where partners build apps, integrations, and workflows on your platform. Event-driven architecture required. High risk: partner quality, security, developer experience. Upside: network effects, switching cost, TAM explosion.

outcomes.clear_success: Marketplace is live with 45 apps. Users built custom workflows, the ecosystem spun $1.8M ARR, and switching costs spiked. Congrats, you run an app store now.
outcomes.partial_success: Marketplace exists with 15 apps and $200k ARR. Developers are "interested" in the way people are interested in a free webinar.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Quality control turned into a full-time job. Low-quality apps tanked trust, so you built a review process and became the app police.
outcomes.soft_failure: Marketplace launched with five apps. Developers are not building and revenue is $50k/year, which barely pays for the "Marketplace" heading.
outcomes.catastrophe: A marketplace app got hacked and exposed data for 10,000 users. The hole was in your infra, so you ate the lawsuits and shut the marketplace down for three months.

title: Workflow Automation Builder
description: Add a no-code workflow builder (Zapier-style) that lets users automate repetitive tasks without code. Complex UI/UX problem. High risk: feature creep, UX complexity, support burden. Upside: engagement +50%, enterprise lock-in.

outcomes.clear_success: Workflow builder is live. 52% of users built at least one workflow, engagement rose 55%, enterprise customers are locked in, and churn dropped 8%. You accidentally made quitting painful.
outcomes.partial_success: The builder works. 28% of users tried it and engagement is up 25%. Solid, not universal, but nobody is throwing tomatoes.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Users built workflows that broke when APIs changed. Workflow breakage is now 30% of the support queue. Congrats on inventing a new fire.
outcomes.soft_failure: The UI is confusing. Only 15% of users built workflows and engagement barely moved. The rest clicked once and backed away slowly.
outcomes.catastrophe: A user built an infinite loop that burned $80k in compute before auto-kill. They demanded compensation, you added rate limits, and legit workflows broke.

title: Natural Language Search
description: Replace keyword search with NLP-powered natural language search that understands intent. High risk: hallucinations, mismatched results, LLM latency. Upside: user satisfaction +40%, feature discovery +30%, engagement +20%.

outcomes.clear_success: Natural language search is live. Satisfaction jumped 38%, users find things twice as fast, engagement is up 22%, and discovery rose 28%. It actually works, which is suspicious.
outcomes.partial_success: NL search works at 78% accuracy and satisfaction is up 15%. Users prefer it to keyword search, even though it is sometimes creatively wrong.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Search latency increased 400ms per query. Users noticed and started timing it like a sport.
outcomes.soft_failure: Accuracy is 62%. Users quietly return to keyword search and engagement barely moves. You built a shiny detour.
outcomes.catastrophe: NL search hallucinated results for 30% of queries. Users saw wrong data, trust cratered, and you disabled it for a month. It is now labeled "experimental" with a disclaimer.

title: Embedded BI Tool
description: Build embedded business intelligence directly in your product (dashboards, KPIs, data exploration). High risk: performance, data freshness, design complexity. Upside: replaces external tools, increases stickiness, new metrics revenue stream.

outcomes.clear_success: Embedded BI is live. Enterprises ditched external tools, dashboards became core, and enterprise ARR is up 32%. Switching costs climbed and nobody is crying about it.
outcomes.partial_success: BI works. 40% of enterprises use it as their primary dashboard and engagement is up 18%. Not a revolution, but a real habit.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Users demanded drill-downs and custom SQL. You accidentally built half a BI platform and a full-time backlog.
outcomes.soft_failure: BI exists but adoption is 15%. Most enterprises still use external tools and revenue impact is minimal. It's a very expensive widget.
outcomes.catastrophe: Large datasets crashed browsers. Big-data customers could not use the feature, perf investigations ate six weeks, and the feature is now labeled beta.

title: Mobile App Launch
description: Build native iOS and Android apps to increase mobile engagement and reach. High risk: platform maintenance, app store policies, feature parity. Upside: mobile users +150%, engagement +40%, new user segments (sales reps, field teams).

outcomes.clear_success: Apps are live on both stores. Mobile users jumped 140%, field teams adopted immediately, and mobile engagement is up 42%. The core product got stickier because people check it constantly.
outcomes.partial_success: Apps are live. Mobile usage is up 80% and feature parity with web is 85%. Users are happy, your backlog is not.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Mobile became the primary interface. Desktop usage declined, and you now support two full product experiences like it's totally fine.
outcomes.soft_failure: Apps launched but adoption is 40% of expected. Most users are still desktop-first and the mobile segment never showed up.
outcomes.catastrophe: iOS got rejected for compliance issues. Android shipped with an auth bug that locked users out for eight hours. Emergency patches followed, both platforms were broken for a day, and mobile credibility took a six-month hit.

title: Voice Interface Layer
description: Add voice command interface that lets users control product via voice (Alexa-style). Accessibility feature with enterprise appeal. High risk: accuracy, privacy concerns, user comfort. Upside: accessibility leader, enterprise mandate (compliance), new interaction model.

outcomes.clear_success: Voice interface shipped. 34% tried it, 18% use it regularly, accessibility scores improved, and enterprise compliance deals added $1.2M. Your product now talks back.
outcomes.partial_success: Voice works at 82% accuracy. About 10% of users use it occasionally, and enterprise interest is politely curious.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Privacy concerns exploded. You added a kill-switch and local processing, and complexity went vertical.
outcomes.soft_failure: Voice accuracy is 68%. Users find it faster to click. The feature is mostly a party trick.
outcomes.catastrophe: Voice misheard 'delete archived items' as 'delete account' and wiped a customer's account. GDPR violation, lawsuit, and you disabled voice deletes forever with permanent credits.

title: Customer Health Scoring AI
description: Build AI-powered health scoring for CSM teams (predicts churn, expansion, renewal risk). ML model trained on 5 years of customer data. High risk: model bias, privacy, model drift. Upside: CSM efficiency +60%, proactive retention, enterprise positioning.

outcomes.clear_success: Health scoring deployed to 80 CSM teams. Churn prediction accuracy hit 89%, efficiency is up 55%, and 23 at-risk renewals were saved. CSMs now trust the robot.
outcomes.partial_success: Health scoring works at 76% accuracy. Teams use it for 60% of accounts and efficiency improved 25%. Not magic, but useful.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: CSMs started gaming the score with 'health hygiene' instead of real adoption work. The metric became a mirror, not a map.
outcomes.soft_failure: Accuracy is 64%. CSMs do not trust it, adoption is low, and efficiency gains are minimal. The AI is mostly a slide deck.
outcomes.catastrophe: The model showed bias against certain cohorts. Startups got flagged as high-risk, CSMs neglected them, and you had to audit publicly. PR damage and trust cratered.

title: No-Code Integration Builder
description: Build visual integration builder (Zapier-style) that lets users connect to external systems without engineering. High complexity, high reward. Risk: scope creep, coverage gaps, support. Upside: new customer segment (operations teams), ecosystem plays, partnership value.

outcomes.clear_success: No-code builder is live with 120+ integrations. Ops teams adopted immediately, enterprise deals closed 40% faster, and integration requests dropped 70%. Engineering briefly felt feelings.
outcomes.partial_success: Builder ships with 45 integrations. Ops teams adoption is about 30% and it covers 80% of needs. Good enough to stop some tickets.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Users built integrations that broke your architecture. You added guard rails and a new category of support tickets.
outcomes.soft_failure: Builder covers only 20 integrations. Most still require engineering, and ROI is questionable. You built a fancy form.
outcomes.catastrophe: A user built a runaway data sync that replicated endlessly and cost $120k in compute before auto-kill. They demanded compensation, you added permanent rate limits, and legit use cases broke.
